awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2018 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Laure Flapan is "Hodge Theory of Families of Varieties". The host institution for the fellowship is the Northeastern University, and the sponsoring scientist is Emanuele Macri.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Intellectual Merit of the Project

The goal of this project was to explore the connections between Hodge theory and famililies of smooth projective varieties. The following are products of the NSF support the P.I. has received as part of this project.



"The geometry of antisymplectic involutions, I" (with E. Macrì, K. O'Grady, G. Saccà) The PI and collaborators study the geometry of the fixed loci of involutions defined Hodge-theoretically on certain hyperkähler manifolds.


"On product identities and the Chow rings of holomorphic symplectic varieties" (with I. Barros, A. Marian, and R. Silversmith)

The PI and collaborators study the Chow ring of algebraic subvarieties of hyperkähler varieties arising as  moduli spaces of stable sheaves on a K3 surface and verify certain identities in these Chow rings.


"Complete families of indecomposable non-simple abelian varieties"

The PI uses group actions on the moduli space of principally polarized abelian varieties to construct complete families of abelian varieties whose connected monodromy groups have a fixed decomposition type.


"Monodromy of Kodaira fibrations of genus 3"
The PI uses group actions on the moduli space of principally polarized abelian threefolds to classify connected monodromy groups of certain algebraic surfaces, called Kodaira fibrations, which are fibered entirely by smooth algebraic curves.  


"Period integrals and Hodge modules" (with R. Walters and X. Zhao)\\

The period integrals of a family of smooth algebraic varieties encodes the way the complex structure of the variety changes as one moves in the family. The PI and collaborators formulate a notion of period integrals attached to any Hodge module, thereby defining a perverse sheaf defined on the entirety of a family of (possibly non-smooth) algebraic varieties which encodes the changing of the complex structure throughout the family.


"Geometry of Schreieder's varieties and some elliptic and K3 moduli curves"

The PI describes varieties constructed by Schreieder for their noteworthy Hodge-theoretic properties as universal families of elliptic and K3 moduli curves.


"Chow motives associated to certain algebraic Hecke characters" (with J. Lang)

The PI and collaborator examine the relationship between certain L functions attached to algebraic Hecke characters and Chow motives attached to simple factors in the Jacobians of certain planar curves.




Broader impacts of the project
While supported by the NSF through this project, the P.I. has been active in the communication and transfer of knowledge by giving talks. She gave 12 invited conference\workshop talks and 20 invited seminar/colloquium talks including talks in the United States, Canda, and Europe.  Her many talks serve not only to disseminate knowledge and enhance the international connections that strengthen the mathematics community as a whole, but by increasing the visibility of women mathematicians, particularly women algebraic geometers, the P.I. serves as a role model for younger female algebraic geometers.

As part of her commitment to mathematical engagement and transfer of knowledge, the P.I. has also been actively involved in conference and seminar organization. While a postdoc at Northeastern University, the P.I. also co-organized both the Geometry, Physics, and Representation Theory (GPRT) research seminar as well as the ``Pick My Brain seminar'', a more informal seminar aimed at postdocs with the intention of fostering collaborations and new connections amongst mathematical areas. Additionally, the P.I. co-organized a special session entitled ``Geometry and arithmetic of hyperkähler manifolds" at the AMS Virtual Southeastern Sectional Meeting in Fall 2020. Beginning in Fall 2020, the P.I. also co-organized (with Arend Bayer, Emanuele Macr\`i, Evgeny Shinder, and Xiaolei Zhao) a weekly online seminar entitled ``Derived Seminar'' focused around derived categories in algebraic geometry with an average weekly attendance of 70+ participants.

The P.I. has undertaken mentoring roles in numerous capacities.  In 2018 the P.I. served as a problem session leader and official mentor for the ``Graduate Workshop in Algebraic Geometry for Women and Mathematicians of Minority Genders'' held at Harvard and MIT. Additionally, the P.I. organized the ``Women at AGNES'' event at the Fall 2019 Algebraic Geometry Northeastern Series (AGNES) at Boston College, a social event designed to foster community and a support network among women algebraic geometers across various levels of seniority. Since coming to  Michigan State University one year ago, the P.I. has become an associated faculty member for the Michigan State chapter of the Association for Women in Mathematics (AWM).
